description: Create an immersive 3D scrollytelling portfolio called 'Go Mods' with React Three Fiber and GSAP. The site should feature: 1) A gamified loading state with 'INITIALIZING GO MODS PROTOCOL...' text and boot-up animation, with a 'Start System' button that triggers camera zoom into the scene. 2) Hero section with a 3D floating workbench in a dark void, featuring a holographic emitter projecting a rotating wireframe, with bold 'GO MODS' typography and subtitle 'Innovative 3D Modeling & Animation / Ready for the Metaverse'. 3) Scrollytelling projects tunnel where camera flies forward through void as user scrolls, with floating virtual screens passing by showing: Character Rigs, Environment Design, and Process & Topology sections. 4) About console section styled as a command terminal with text 'Mission: Bringing ideas to life through innovative 3D creation' and a 'Nostalgia Mode' toggle that switches terminal colors between green and pink. 5) Permanent 'STATUS: ONLINE / OPEN TO COMMISSION' beacon in top-right corner with pulsing green dot that expands on hover to show email mcrevatis03@gmail.com. Design aesthetic: Deep Void Purple (#1a0b2e) background with Terminal Green (#00ff41) accents, industrial sci-fi vibe inspired by Glitch Productions. Optimize for 60FPS performance with mobile fallback.

Update all branding from 'Go Mods' to 'PhillMods'. Change the loading screen text to 'INITIALIZING PHILLMODS PROTOCOL...', update the hero section main heading to 'PHILLMODS', and ensure all references throughout the site use the correct brand name 'PhillMods'.

ACT 1 - SYSTEM INITIALIZATION: Enhance the hero section with a more detailed terminal boot sequence showing line-by-line text: 'INITIALIZING PHILLMODS PROTOCOL...', 'LOADING CREATIVE SYSTEMS...', 'READY FOR COMMISSION'. The 3D wireframe should progressively fill with texture/color as user scrolls. Add parallax effect with wireframe rotating on Y-axis during scroll. Include custom neon green crosshair cursor, floating particle system with green code snippets/vertices in background. Update hero text to: 'PHILLMODS - Innovative 3D Modeling & Animation - Ready for the Metaverse'. Add glowing green outlined 'COMMISSION TODAY' button with subtle pulse animation.

ACT 2 - THE CREATIVE VOID: Transform project section into floating 'Project Capsules' drifting through space at varying depths and speeds. Each capsule should use glass-morphism design containing: rotating 3D model preview, project title in terminal green, tech specs like 'Blender | Unreal Engine | Game-Ready'. On hover: capsule slows rotation, enlarges 10%, green glow intensifies. On click: expand to full-screen modal with high-res rotating 3D viewer, wireframe toggle switch, project breakdown showing 'Polycount | Textures | Rigged'. Include 4 projects: 'Goat Character V1' (wireframe and textured), 'Environment Pack', 'Character Rigging Demo', 'Unreal Engine Real-Time Rendering'. Add floating badges that drift by: 'UNREAL ENGINE CERTIFIED', 'CLEAN TOPOLOGY SPECIALIST', 'GAME-READY ASSETS', 'PBR TEXTURING EXPERT'.

ACT 3 - OPEN NETWORK: Create holographic terminal interface for contact section. Add grid floor with neon green wireframe grid materializing beneath. Central holographic display shows status: 'STATUS: ONLINE | OPEN TO COMMISSION' with pulsing green beacon. Contact section includes Discord: @pheliabobelia with logo, email form with terminal aesthetic, and 'Response Time: 24-48 HR TURNAROUND'. Footer shows 'PHILLMODS © 2025 | Bringing Ideas to Life Through Innovation', Privacy Policy and Terms of Service links, social media icons (Discord, ArtStation, LinkedIn) in neon green.

Add WIREFRAME TOGGLE feature: Button labeled 'SHOW WIREFRAME' that toggles 3D models between solid render and wireframe view throughout the site. Add PROCESS VIEWER: Timeline slider showing model evolution from Concept Sketch → Blockout → Wireframe → Textured → Final Render that users can scrub through. Add REAL-TIME STATS DASHBOARD with live counters: 'Projects Completed: 47', 'Total Vertices Modeled: 2.4M', 'Coffee Consumed: ∞'. Add EASTER EGG: Hidden Konami code (↑↑↓↓←→←→BA) that triggers 'matrix mode' with green code rain falling over scene.

Add comprehensive SERVICES section showcasing: Custom Character Modeling, Game-Ready Asset Creation, Rigging & Animation, Unreal Engine Integration, Technical Art Consultation. Include mission statement: 'At PhilMods, my mission is to bring your ideas to life through innovative 3D creation. I specialize in high-quality models and animations that cater to your unique requirements.' Add tagline 'Transforming Imagination into Immersive 3D Realities'. Add CTA: 'Ready to bring your vision to life? Let's create something extraordinary.'

Update all branding from 'PhillMods' to 'PhilMods' (single L). Change all instances throughout the site including: loading screen text 'INITIALIZING PHILMODS PROTOCOL...', hero heading 'PHILMODS', terminal console references, footer '© 2025 PHILMODS', mission statement references, and any other mentions of the brand name.
Verify and ensure the main hero title displays 'PHILMODS' with exactly one L (not PHILLMODS). Check the hero heading specifically and make sure it shows 'PHILMODS' correctly.

Replace the icosahedron geometry with the MEOW character 3D model. Import useGLTF from @react-three/drei and load '/meow.gltf'. Replace both the wireframe and solid icosahedron meshes with the loaded GLTF model using primitive component. Keep the same rotation animations and scroll-based effects. Position the model at [0, 0, 0] with scale starting at 1.5 (adjust if needed). Maintain the terminal green color scheme - apply emissive material with terminal green color to the model. Keep the Float animation and all existing lighting. Add useGLTF.preload('/meow.gltf') at the bottom of the file for optimization.

Fix the missing MEOW model issue. Since the .gltf file requires external dependencies (meow.bin and emissive.png) that aren't available, revert to using the wireframe character image at /wireframe-character.png as the main 3D centerpiece. Remove the MEOW model component and GLB loading code. Ensure the wireframe character image is prominently displayed in the hero section with the floating animation, glow effects, and scan-line overlay. Keep all the scrolling animations and terminal green aesthetic. Make the wireframe character the star of the show - scale it appropriately and ensure it's clearly visible with the holographic effects.

Polish the entire site experience. Ensure smooth scrolling performance, verify all sections are properly spaced, check that the project capsules are clickable and display correctly in modals, confirm the Status beacon is visible and functional, test the Konami code easter egg works, verify the contact form and social links are working, and ensure the overall aesthetic is cohesive with the terminal green and void purple theme throughout.

Replace the current hero centerpiece with the full 3D MEOW character model. Import useGLTF from @react-three/drei and load '/meow.gltf' (all dependencies are now in public: meow.gltf, meow.bin, emissive.png). Create a MeowCharacter component that loads the model with primitive object. Position at [0, 0, 0] with scale 0.8 to start (may need adjustment). Add Float animation with speed 1.5, rotationIntensity 0.3, floatIntensity 0.5. Add scroll-based rotation on Y-axis. Wrap in Suspense with a loading fallback. Keep the terminal green lighting focused on the model with pointLights. Add useGLTF.preload('/meow.gltf'). Replace the wireframe shape in the hero section with this full 3D model.

Optimize the 3D model presentation. Ensure proper camera positioning to frame the character nicely. Add additional lighting: spotlight from above at [0, 8, 5] with intensity 2 and terminal green color, rim light from behind at [0, 2, -5] with intensity 1. If the model appears too dark, increase ambient light to 0.6. If scale needs adjustment for visibility, try values between 0.5 and 1.5. Ensure the model rotates smoothly as user scrolls and maintains the floating animation.

Change the terminal green accent color (#00ff41) to pink (#ff41b4) across the entire site. Update all instances including: text colors, button borders and hover states, glows and shadows, particle effects, status beacon color, wireframe colors, emissive materials on 3D models, spotlight colors, cursor color, link hover states, input focus borders, project capsule borders and glows, badge colors, terminal text colors, scan-line effects, and any other UI elements using the green accent. Make the pink the new primary accent color throughout the site while keeping the deep void purple (#1a0b2e) background.

Update the floating skill badges in the projects section. Remove 'PBR TEXTURING EXPERT', 'UNREAL ENGINE CERTIFIED', and 'CLEAN TOPOLOGY SPECIALIST'. Replace with exactly three badges: 'BLENDER', 'RIGGING', and 'GAME READY ASSETS'. Keep the same floating animation, pink styling, and positioning for these badges.

Update the project capsules copy to reflect this is a growing portfolio. Change the project descriptions to be more creative, interactive, and forward-looking. For example, instead of generic tech specs, add engaging placeholder text like 'More coming soon...', 'Watch this space evolve', 'Project details loading...', or 'Stay tuned for the full story'. Make the tone playful and hint that exciting project details will be added in the future. Keep the project titles (Goat Character V1, Environment Pack, Character Rigging Demo, Unreal Engine Real-Time Rendering) but make the descriptions feel alive and anticipatory rather than static.

Add an interactive empty state or 'Coming Soon' visual element to some project capsules. Maybe add a pulsing 'Work in Progress' indicator or animated placeholder that shows this portfolio is actively being built. Make it feel like a living, evolving showcase rather than a finished static gallery. Use creative copy like 'Loading creativity...', 'Building something amazing...', or 'New projects materializing...' Keep the pink and purple aesthetic with animated elements.
Remove the real-time stats dashboard that shows 'Projects Completed: 47', 'Total Vertices Modeled: 2.4M', 'Coffee Consumed: ∞'. Delete this entire section from the site.

Add a playful pink wireframe rat that runs across the screen as the user scrolls. Create a small 3D rat mesh using Three.js geometry (combine spheres and cylinders for body, head, tail, legs). Apply pink wireframe material (#ff41b4). Animate the rat to run from left to right across the screen when user scrolls past a certain point (maybe around 50% scroll). Add running animation by moving legs and bobbing body. Position it so it runs across the viewport at mid-screen height. Make it disappear off screen after crossing. Add subtle squeak sound effect if possible or just visual comedy. This is for comic relief and personality!

Fix the pink wireframe rat so it's clearly visible. Ensure the rat appears on screen when scrolling. Increase the size of the rat (make it bigger, maybe 150-200px tall), ensure it has proper z-index to appear above all content, make the animation slower so it's easier to see, and position it at a clear viewport position (maybe vertical center of screen). Change the scroll trigger to activate earlier (around 30% scroll instead of 50%) and make the animation last longer (maybe 4-5 seconds instead of quick). Add a pink glow/shadow to make it pop against the dark background. Test that it's actually rendering and visible.

Reposition the pink wireframe rat as a contextual easter egg that appears at a meaningful moment during scroll. Instead of appearing at a random percentage, make it appear between major sections - like running across the screen right after the user scrolls past the project capsules section and before the services/about section. This makes it feel like the rat is 'inspecting the work' or 'delivering creative energy' between sections. Adjust the scroll trigger to detect when user is in the transition zone between Projects and Services sections. Make it feel like a delightful surprise that fits the narrative flow of the portfolio.

Update the footer section. Remove the Privacy Policy and Terms of Service links. Change copyright to '© 2026 PHILMODS'. Add a new line underneath with the text 'itdosentmatter' in a smaller, subtle font. Add a tron blue (cyan #00d9ff) 'Live Long and Prosper' Vulcan salute hand icon (🖖 emoji or SVG) as a signature element next to or below the text. Style it with a cyan glow to match the tron aesthetic as a personal signature touch.

Update the footer signature. Remove the 'itdosentmatter' text completely. Change the Vulcan salute emoji 🖖 color from tron blue to brown (#8B4513 or similar brown tone). Place the text 'ELVTE' underneath the emoji. Keep the emoji glowing effect but in brown tones instead of cyan.

Update the footer signature styling. Keep the Vulcan salute emoji 🖖 in brown color (#8B4513) but change the glow effect to tron blue/cyan (#00d9ff). So the emoji itself is brown but it glows with cyan/tron blue shadows and effects around it. Keep 'ELVTE' text underneath.
Change the 'ELVTE' text color to tron blue/cyan (#00d9ff). Keep the emoji brown with cyan glow, but make the ELVTE text itself cyan colored with the cyan glow effect.
Change the Vulcan salute emoji from 🖖 to 🖖🏾 (with medium-dark skin tone modifier). Keep the tron blue glow effect on the emoji and the ELVTE text underneath in tron blue.

Add smooth scroll functionality to the 'START YOUR PROJECT' button in the Services section. When clicked, it should scroll the user down to the contact form/message box section. Use scrollIntoView with smooth behavior or a scroll library to create a smooth scrolling animation to the contact form.

Set up the contact form to send emails when submitted. Since this is a static site, integrate a third-party email service like Web3Forms or Formspree. When a user fills out the contact form (name, email, message fields), submitting should send an email to mcrevatis03@gmail.com. Add form validation, a loading state during submission, and success/error messages. The form should show 'Message sent!' on success or an error message if it fails. Add a subtle animation/feedback when the form is submitted successfully.

Add a featured section underneath the 'START YOUR PROJECT' button in the Services section. Image path: /home/user/Attachments/d6f928be-4a22-4345-b58d-3b2faa80947e.png. This is the MIT Reality Hack neon sign logo. Add text above the image: 'MIT Reality Hack Art 2026 Selected Exhibitor' in elegant typography. Display the glowing MIT Reality Hack image with pink/purple neon glow effects to match the neon aesthetic. Below the logo, add a photo placeholder (empty frame or silhouette icon) for a profile photo. Under the placeholder, add the name 'Mya Crevatis' in tron blue (#00d9ff) with subtle glow. Style this as a featured achievement/recognition section with proper spacing and visual hierarchy.

Polish the MIT Reality Hack featured section design. Make the neon sign image prominent with animated glow effects (pulsing or subtle shimmer). Add a elegant border or frame around the photo placeholder. Ensure the text 'MIT Reality Hack Art 2026 Selected Exhibitor' is positioned clearly above (could be in a banner style or elegant header). Make 'Mya Crevatis' stand out in tron blue with proper spacing. Add subtle animations on hover or entrance. This should feel like a prestigious achievement showcase within the portfolio.

Rebrand PhilMods as a small creative studio instead of a solo operation. Update all copy from first-person singular to plural. Change 'my mission' to 'our mission', 'I specialize' to 'we specialize', 'I bring' to 'we bring', etc. Update the mission statement in the Services section from 'At PhilMods, my mission is to bring your ideas to life through innovative 3D creation. I specialize in high-quality models and animations that cater to your unique requirements.' to use 'our mission', 'we specialize', 'we bring', etc. Update any other instances throughout the site where singular voice is used. Make it feel like a collaborative creative studio team.

Reposition the pink wireframe rat easter egg to appear in the space between Mya Crevatis' name/photo (MIT Reality Hack section) and the PhilMods contact form/console box. Update the scroll trigger refs to detect when user is in the transition zone between the MIT Achievement section and the Contact section. The rat should run across right after scrolling past Mya's achievement showcase and before reaching the contact terminal.

Adjust the pink wireframe rat positioning and behavior. Move the rat higher vertically to run in the free space between Mya's name and the top of the PhilMods console window (try position around 35vh or 40vh instead of current position). Add scroll direction detection: when user scrolls down, rat runs left to right (normal), but when user scrolls up past that section, rat runs right to left (reverse direction). Implement logic to track previous scroll position and determine scroll direction, then flip the animation and starting position accordingly.

Debug and fix the pink wireframe rat visibility issue. Increase z-index to 99999 to ensure it's above all content. Make the rat even larger (250-300px tall) so it's impossible to miss. Simplify the scroll trigger - make it activate at a specific scroll percentage (like 70-80% down the page) instead of relying on refs. Add a more obvious visual - maybe add a bright pink background glow or trail. Test that the rat actually renders and animates. Consider adding console.log to verify trigger points. Make the animation slower (6-7 seconds) so users have time to see it. Ensure the rat appears in the correct viewport position relative to the MIT section and contact form.

Completely rebuild the pink wireframe rat with reliable logic. Use Intersection Observer API to trigger when the MIT Achievement section becomes visible in viewport. Remove all complex scroll calculations. Make the rat always start from a consistent position (left edge of screen at vertical center). When MIT section is 50% visible, trigger the rat to run left-to-right across screen. Keep it simple: one direction, one trigger, reliable visibility. Increase size to 300px, ensure z-index 99999, position at fixed 50vh. Add a bright pink glow background div that's impossible to miss. Test that it actually renders by making it visible on page load for 2 seconds as a test, then switch to scroll trigger.

As a fallback, if the scroll-triggered rat still doesn't work, add a simple always-visible small animated rat icon in the corner of the MIT Achievement section that subtly moves/bounces. This ensures users see SOME rat animation even if the scroll trigger fails. Make it a small cute 60px rat that sits in the top-right corner of the MIT neon sign image and does a gentle bounce animation. This is a backup to guarantee rat visibility.
Remove the small corner rat that's sitting on the MIT neon sign image. Remove the CornerRat component entirely from the MIT Achievement section.

Fix the scroll-triggered rat to appear in the correct location. The rat should run across the screen AFTER user scrolls past 'Mya Crevatis' name, in the empty space BEFORE reaching the contact terminal box that says 'STATUS: ONLINE'. Update the Intersection Observer to watch specifically for when the Mya name text has been scrolled past. Position the rat to run in the gap/whitespace between the MIT Achievement section end and the Contact section start. Make sure it's running in empty space, not overlapping any content. Adjust vertical position if needed to be clearly in the transition zone between sections.

Adjust the pink wireframe rat animation speed for smoother movement. Change the animation duration to find the sweet spot - try 4 seconds instead of 5 for snappier movement. Also refine the timing function/easing - use a smooth ease-in-out or cubic-bezier for more natural acceleration and deceleration. Make the leg animation frequency match the new speed so it looks like natural running. Test different durations between 3.5-4.5 seconds to find what feels smoothest across that gap.

Remove 'Unreal Engine Integration' and 'Technical Art Consultation' from the Services section. Keep only: Custom Character Modeling, Game-Ready Asset Creation, and Rigging & Animation. Update the services list to show these three services with proper spacing and styling.

Optimize 3D rendering for mobile devices. Add mobile detection (check window width < 768px or use touch detection). For mobile: reduce MEOW model scale slightly for better framing, reduce particle counts, simplify lighting (fewer lights with lower intensity), reduce Float animation intensity, and ensure the Canvas components render smoothly. Add performance optimizations like reducing shadow quality or disabling expensive effects on mobile. Test that the 3D scene loads and animates on mobile without crashing or lagging.

Ensure mobile touch interactions work properly. Make sure scroll-based 3D animations work with touch scrolling on mobile devices. Verify the MEOW character model displays correctly in mobile viewport, adjust camera position or FOV if needed for mobile. Add loading optimization - maybe show a simpler wireframe version while the full model loads on mobile. Ensure all 3D elements (hero model, floating badges, particles) are visible and performant on mobile screens.

Remove the circular photo placeholder from the MIT Achievement section. Delete the entire photo placeholder div that shows the decorative rings and scan effects. Keep the neon sign, the achievement text, and Mya Crevatis name, but remove the empty photo frame.

Rebuild the rat easter egg from scratch with the simplest possible approach. Create a test mode first: make the rat visible and run across screen immediately on page load for 3 seconds to verify it renders. After confirming visibility, add a simple scroll trigger: when scrollY > 3000 pixels (adjust based on actual page height), trigger the rat. Make it HUGE (400px), bright pink with massive glow, positioned at exactly 50vh center screen, z-index 999999. Add obvious console.log statements showing when rat triggers. Remove all complex logic - just: scroll past point → rat runs left to right → done. Test on both mobile and desktop.

After the test rat works, fine-tune the scroll trigger to activate specifically after the MIT Achievement section. Use getBoundingClientRect on the MIT section to get its exact position, then trigger rat when that section has scrolled past viewport top by at least 200px. Keep the rat simple, large, and obvious. Add a visual debug indicator (small pink dot in corner) that shows when the trigger zone is active. This way we can verify the logic is working even if the rat isn't visible.
